Award.AwardTitle: Engineering All-Inorganic Quantum Dot Heterojunction Photovoltaics Through Surface Chemical Manipulations

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Kagan, Cherie
Proposal Number: 1236406
Institution: University of Pennsylvania
Title: Engineering All-Inorganic Quantum Dot Heterojunction Photovoltaics Through Surface Chemical Manipulations

Colloidal semiconductor quantum (QDs) promise low-cost, large-area, high performance solar photovoltaics (PVs) as they may be processed from solution like inks and they have size, shape, and composition-dependent electronic and optical properties uniquely allowing the design and fabrication of all-inorganic materials from nanoscale building blocks. The challenge is to harness the prized electronic properties of these solution-processable QDs in solid thin films where facile charge transport and doping are required to engineer junctions for efficient solar PVs and more broadly for semiconductor electronic and optoelectronic devices. The large area surface (to volume), stoichiometric balance, and coupling between QDs greatly affect charge carrier type and transport in QD solid thin films.

This project will carry out chemical transformations to manipulate the surface chemistry and stoichiometry of QDs in solid state thin films while probing in-situ their surface chemistry and electrical properties to design high mobility, n- and p-type QD thin films and high efficiency pn heterojunction PVs. For example, wet-chemical synthetic methods yield macroscopic quantities of colloidal semiconductor QDs that may be tailored in size, shape, and composition and deposited like inks by spin- casting and dip-coating to form large-area, uniform QD thin films. Here, the PI will exchange the QDs in thin films using the recently developed ammonium thiocyanate treatment to form strongly electronically coupled and nearly bare QDs, providing sites for subsequent chemical transformations. Electrochemical, optical and electrical measurements will be used to characterize the energy levels and carrier type, trapping, and mobility as we modify QD films. High mobility, long carrier lifetime QD films with electronic structures tailored to define large junction offsets will be integrated into solar cells and optimized to form broad band, high absorption QD films for efficient solar PVs.

The proposed research activities will develop understanding of the role of surface, stoichiometry, and extrinsic atoms in weakly quantum confined, wider band gap and more strongly quantum confined, smaller band gap QDs. The role of the surface is important in designing high carrier mobility, n- and p-type materials that impact not only solar photovoltaics, but the design of a broad range of sustainable electronic and optoelectronic devices; low-power electronics, energy harvesting thermoelectrics, and low-power light-emitting diodes; pursued from solution-processable QD materials. The fundamental understanding and technological developments will expand knowledge and teaching of nanostructured materials and of processes for chemical transformations and design of materials, applicable to the growing toolbox of nanostructured materials. The program will provide an interdisciplinary research experience for undergraduate and graduate students. It will also provide an opportunity for the students and PI to share the science and engineering of sustainable and nanoscale technologies with K-12 students and teachers, the public, and the scientific community through demos, presentations, and formal and extramural coursework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectural Merit:

Colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals, also known as quantum dots (QDs), are prized for their size, shape, and composition-dependent electronic and optical properties and their low-cost, large-area, solution-based deposition and integration into devices. These colloidal QDs promise an alternative materials class to realize low-cost, yet high efficiency solar photovoltaic devices. However the surface chemsitry and incomplete bonding of these inherently high surface-area to volume ratio QDs materials presents a grand challenge to control QD carrier concentration, mobility, and lifetime.

Under the support of this NSF grant, we introduced mild, solution-based ligand exchange processes and metal salt treatments that allowed us to engineer the carrier type, concnentration, mobility and lifetime in colloidal II-VI and IV-VI QDs. The long ligands used to synthesize colloidal QDs introduces large spacing between QDs once assembled to form thin films solids and therefore inhibit the transport of charge. To realize electronically active materials, the long ligands are exchanged with more compact chemistries. However the solvents and ligand chemistries used to deposit and exchange the QDs may alter the chemistry and therefore electronic properties of QD thin films. We showed that using solution-based metal salt treatments we could control the surface stoichiometry (e.g. excess metal or chalcogen in II-VI and IV-VI semiconductor nanostructures) and therefore the electron and hole concentration (over five orders of magnitude) and their mobility in QD thin films and use these treatments to repair surface trap states that limit carrier lifetime.

We exploited these methods to fabricate QD-based heterojunction photovoltaic devices and to combine materials to enhance device performance. We integrated a colloidal CdSe QD thin film window/buffer layer in between the p-type PbS and n-type ZnO layer commonly used in QD heterojucnction photovoltaic devices. The added CdSe QD layer increased the solar cell device performance by 20%.

 

Broader Impacts:

We showed the ligand exchange and metal salt treatments introduced in this grant to control the carrier type, concentration and mobility in colloidal QD materials is broadly applicable to different zero-dimensional QD chemistries and to one-dimensional quantum wires. This control over the electronic properties of QD materials is more broadly applicable to their integration in electronic, thermoelectric and other optoelectronic devices.

This grant supported the education of one postdoctoral fellow, three graduate students, and the independent study, summer experience, and senior theses of five undergraduate students who have continued their careers as faculty and researchers in industry and their studies in graduate programs. The principal investigator and her students applied the studies in this grant and shared the science and engineering of nanoscale materials and photovoltaic devices in the educational development of K-12 students in the Philadelphia community at: 1) The Philadelphia Science Festival, 2) Philly Materials Day, 3) Women in Compuer Science High School Day, 4) Penn's Grils in Engineering, Math, and Science (GEMS) summer camp for 6th-8th grade girls, and 5) Penn's Management and Technology summer camp. The project also contributed to a new sophomore-level course required in Electrical and Systems Engineering entitled, "Electronic, Photonic, and Electromechanical Devices," which intregrates a lecture with a hands-on laboratory to share the fundamentals and then fabricate and characterize solar cells from conventional and non-traditional semiconductor materials.
